of something I know
modular taverns so you can drink any way you like to begin with prepare many
crafting sticks using the wood technique described back in video 7 however you
only need to prepare one side a good rule of thumb is that one crafting stick
will be needed for a single space thus for per tile in addition prepare some
jumbo crafting sticks these can also be found in your crafting store make sure
that they are three quarters of an inch wide again you only need to prepare one
side of them and the rule of thumb is that you will get two walls from each
jumbo crafting stick as always you'll first cut out your
foundations in this video I will be building a corner tile the dimensions
are different for these tavern tiles so disregard the dimensions I gave in video
2 and use these instead the reason will become apparent later on as you assemble
the walls next take your dollar store foam board and cut a 3/4 inch strip we
will need one piece to be two and a quarter inch and the other to be two and
a half inch peel the paper off of one side use your knife with a fresh blade
to add a cobblestone texture to accomplish this I dragged two waving
lines across to divide the height roughly into thirds note how I waive the
knife as I'm scoring the foam then score lines at sporadic distances and angles
last use your mechanical pencil to widen and deepen all the lines that you scored
next glue on the corrugation cover in this case in doing a corner tile so I
only cover two sides then apply a healthy base coat to the foundation
including the corrugation cover of dark brown in this case I'm using my go-to
burnt umber now take one jumbo popsicle stick and cut it to length
if in doubt as to the length simply measure your foundation to see what you
need in this case for the corner tile I know that I need two of them each at two
and a quarter inches in length glue them to the foundation with the finished side
inward ensure that your glue gun has been sitting a while so it's very hot
and apply a fairly thick bead and as you attach the wall take a second or two to
press it in this gives the glue time to sink into
the corrugation and prevent any from oozing out hold for a good 20 seconds to
be absolutely sure that the glue is fully hardened the great thing about
double corrugated cardboard here is the surface area I know how this looks in
the picture but again you'll be surprised at how strong this is if you
use heavy glue and work patiently and deliberately
time to create the spaces take a standard crafting stick and cut lengths
of one and a quarter-inch light blue the first one to the lower right corner of
the tile no matter which way you're looking at the tile such that it is
perpendicular to yourself or as you see it on the screen right now up and down
this is extremely important if you adhere to this rule it guarantees that
no matter what orientation your tiles are placed in you'll always have a nice
checkerboard pattern of alternating directions for your spaces which looks
very nice I have a demonstration of this later on now the width of three crafting
sticks is not quite one and a quarter inch so you'll see here I'm placing a
gauge down temporarily and the second piece I attach is actually the other
side of the space the third plank to go down is the one in the middle I do this
in order to ensure that the middle piece is evenly spaced between the other two
now cut some lengths at 1 inch light glue them to the foundation
perpendicular to your first space again glue the two outer boards first and the
middle one last the remaining two spaces in this corner
tile only fit two boards each as you would expect
you now apply a neutral gray base coat to
your cobblestone texture including all four sides stab at the cracks to ensure
that you get paint all the way down in there for this corner tile
I will first attach the smaller of the two cobblestone walls ensure your glue
is nice and hot and attach it press firmly if you don't the glue may not
squeeze totally flat which will introduce added width to your wall this
is a big deal because if you use clip-on features such as the doors from video 5
they may not fit also if the wall is more than 1/4 inch thick
you run the risk of error propagation as described in video 1 anyway next place
the longer piece and ensure you glue it to the shorter end of the piece as well
to seal solidify and reinforce that entire corner from here pick a lighter
gray I'm using slate gray which has a very slight hint of blue to it pick out
random stones with this color maybe 4 or 5 per side you can use other colors as
well depending on your personal taste here's an example where I also picked
out some stones with pebble okay so let's build a rudimentary tavern
here I'm at about half proper speed here because I'm only using one hand the
other one is holding my phone to shoot this but you can see you could build a
structure in pretty quick order if you wanted to I am curious as to how
everyone else would handle cobblestone flagstone something I really struggled
with before settling on this very simple approach no dry brushing you may notice
some exposed chipping while you cut the wood and if that happens you can just
touch it up with your base coat burnt umber or whatever you used so we'll clip
on a door here there's a hallway or a foyer leading into it whatever so here's
a we'll treat this potion rack as a liquor cabinet and a bartender and maybe
just to stand in for a bar since I don't have one built couple of patrons notice
there on the perimeter spaces but they're 1-inch bases still fit and a
couple of tables so here we go a very basic rudimentary tavern thrown together
in short order and again notice here the spaces alternate direction and that will
always be the case as long as you build them consistently so whatever you're
looking at the tile lower right make it go the same way I am why lock thank you
